papers.title: A new genetic-engineering technology could spell the end for malaria
papers.desc: In tests, a gene drive has already driven a small, caged mosquito population to extinction

papers.title: An adaptation of “White Teeth” shows how Britain has changed
papers.desc: Eighteen years after Zadie Smith’s debut novel was published, its multicultural optimism is a distant memory

papers.title: How airports use biometric technology
papers.desc: Airlines want to speed up the boarding process with facial-recognition software

papers.title: How the “mighty woman with a torch” came into being
papers.desc: Francesca Lidia Viano takes the reader back to a time when the Statue of Liberty did not tower over New York Harbour

papers.title: How to bring peace to Libya
papers.desc: The UN’s plan offers the best hope of ending Libya’s chaos, but Italy and France are making things worse

papers.title: Pilots are not high-flyers when it comes to English proficiency
papers.desc: The aviation industry performs worst in a new ranking

papers.title: Sri Lanka’s president calls a snap election
papers.desc: Even though the constitution does not seem to give him the power to do so

papers.title: The Church of England plays a big role in acts of remembrance
papers.desc: But now it emphasises reconciliation, peace and the human sinfulness that lead to war

papers.title: Why the flu of 1918 was so deadly
papers.desc: It may well have killed more people than both world wars combined

papers.title: Why the restoration of felons’ voting rights in Florida is a big deal
papers.desc: Amendment 4 is a boon for democracy in the Sunshine State

papers.title: “They Shall Not Grow Old” brings archive footage to stirring life
papers.desc: The film applies modern production techniques to old film to achieve something poppies and pageantry cannot: immediacy
